Another person died in Grayvoron city in Russia’s Belgorod region, bordering Ukraine, regional Gov.
Russia’s Defense Ministry said both Ukraine and the U.S. bore “responsibility for a deliberate missile strike on civilians.” It said that U.S.-supplied ATACMS missiles were used in the Ukranian attack.
A fresh attack on Kharkiv killed at least one person and wounded 11 on Sunday, according to local officials.
Two people were wounded by falling debris when two Russian missiles were shot down over the Kyiv region overnight, Ukraine´s air force commander Mykola Oleschuk said.
Vadym Filashkin of Ukraine’s partly occupied Donetsk region said that Russian attacks on Saturday killed two people and wounded four.

Russia accuses Ukraine of deadly drone attacks in Crimea's SevastopolWorld World Russia accuses Ukraine of deadly drone attacks in Crimea's SevastopolRussia said four people died and over 100 were wounded in Ukrainian drone and missile attacksFollow on Published On: Mon, 24 Jun 2024 08:00:03 PKTMOSCOW (AP) - Russian authorities said four people died and over 100 were wounded in Ukrainian drone and missile attacks on Sunday, while the second day of Russia's aerial bombing of Kharkiv in northeastern Ukraine killed at least one person.
One person was killed and three injured in Russia’s Belgorod region, bordering Ukraine, when three Ukrainian drones attacked the city of Grayvoron, regional Gov.
A fresh attack on Kharkiv killed at least one person and wounded 10 on Sunday, according to local officials.
Sunday's attacks came after Russia struck Kharkiv on Saturday afternoon with four aerial bombs, hitting a five-story residential building and killing three people.
Vadym Filashkin of Ukraine’s partly occupied Donetsk region said that Russian attacks on Saturday killed two people and wounded four.

Another person died in Grayvoron city in Russia’s Belgorod region, bordering Ukraine, regional Gov.
Air defenses overnight shot down 33 Ukrainian drones over Russia’s western Bryansk, Smolensk, Lipetsk and Tula regions, the Russian Ministry of Defense said Sunday.
A fresh attack on Kharkiv killed at least one person and wounded 11 on Sunday, according to local officials.
In a video address following the attack, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged Ukraine’s partners to bolster its air defenses.
Moscow has not yet commented on the reports, but officials said air defenses shot down a number of drones in the region overnight on Friday.

One person was killed and three were injured in Russia’s Belgorod region, bordering Ukraine, when three Ukrainian drones attacked the city of Grayvoron, regional governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said.
It said that US-supplied ATACMS missiles were used in the Ukrainian attack.
Air defence forces shot down 33 Ukrainian drones over the country’s western Bryansk, Smolensk, Lipetsk and Tula regions.
In a video address following Saturday’s attack, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged Ukraine’s partners to bolster its air defences.
Regional Governor Vadym Filashkin of Ukraine’s partly occupied Donetsk region said that Russian attacks on Saturday killed two people and wounded four.

What is Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed group that could go to all-out war against Israel?
BEIRUT (AP) — After more than eight months of low-scale conflict, Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah are threatening all-out war.
Founded in 1982 during Lebanon’s civil war, Hezbollah’s initial objective was ending Israel’s occupation of southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah and Israel fought a monthlong war that ended in a draw but Israeli bombardment wreaked widespread destruction in southern Lebanon.
Throughout its latest conflict with Israel, Hezbollah has gradually introduced new weapons to its arsenal, especially after Israel began its ground invasion of the southern city of Rafah in Gaza in early May.

BEIRUT (AP) — After more than eight months of low-scale conflict, Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah are threatening all-out war.
File - Supporters of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah group listen to a speech by Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah speaking via a video link, in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Lebanon, Tuesday, May 14, 2024.
Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah have recently ratcheted up their threats of an all-out war.
Founded in 1982 during Lebanon’s civil war, Hezbollah’s initial objective was ending Israel’s occupation of southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah and Israel fought a monthlong war that ended in a draw but Israeli bombardment wreaked widespread destruction in southern Lebanon.

By KAREEM CHEHAYEB The Associated PressBEIRUT (AP) — After more than eight months of low-scale conflict, Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah are threatening all-out war.
Founded in 1982 during Lebanon’s civil war, Hezbollah’s initial objective was ending Israel’s occupation of southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah and Israel fought a monthlong war that ended in a draw but Israeli bombardment wreaked widespread destruction in southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah’s military capabilities have also surged, and it has played a key role in the Syrian civil war, keeping President Bashar al-Assad in power.
Throughout its latest conflict with Israel, Hezbollah has gradually introduced new weapons to its arsenal, especially after Israel began its ground invasion of the southern city of Rafah in Gaza in early May.

MOSCOW: Russia said on Sunday that the United States was “directly responsible” for an attack carried out from Ukra­inian territory with five missiles that killed at least five people, including three children, and injured 124 more in Crimea.
The Russian defence ministry said US specialists had set the missiles’ flight coordinates on the basis of information from US spy satellites, meaning Washington was directly responsible.
The ministry said four missiles were downed but a fifth changed trajectory after being intercepted “with its warhead exploding in the air over the city”.
Russian-installed auth­o­rities in Crimea said missile fragments had fallen just after noon near a beach on the north side of Sevastopol city where locals were holidaying.
At least 124 were inju­red, Russian Health Mini­ster Mikhail Mura­shko said.

Moscow: Russia has blamed the United States for a Ukrainian attack on the Russian-annexed Crimean peninsula after missile fragments fell on beachgoers in an incident that killed four people, including two children, and injured 151 more.
The Russian Defence Ministry said four of the US-delivered Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS) missiles, equipped with cluster warheads, were shot down by air defence systems and the ammunition of a fifth had detonated in mid-air.
Footage shared on Telegram of people seeking treatment on the beach.
Credit: TelegramFootage on Russian state television showed people running from a beach and some people being carried off on sun loungers.
Russian-installed authorities in Crimea said missile fragments had fallen just after noon near a beach on the north side of the city of Sevastopol where locals were on holiday.

Russia said on Sunday that the United States was responsible for a Ukrainian attack on the Russian-annexed Crimean Peninsula with five U.S.-supplied missiles that killed four people, including two children, and injured 151 more.
Footage on Russian state television showed people running from a beach and some people being carried off on sun loungers.
The Defense Ministry said U.S. specialists had set the missiles' flight coordinates on the basis of information from U.S. spy satellites, meaning Washington was directly responsible.
The United States began supplying Ukraine with longer range ATACMS missiles, which have a 300-kilometer (186-mile) range, earlier this year.
Russia will respond to Sunday's attack, the Defense Ministry said, without elaborating.

Moscow: Russia has blamed the United States for a Ukrainian attack on the Russian-annexed Crimean peninsula after missile fragments fell on beachgoers in an incident that killed four people, including two children, and injured 151 more.
The Russian Defence Ministry said four of the US-delivered Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS) missiles, equipped with cluster warheads, were shot down by air defence systems and the ammunition of a fifth had detonated in mid-air.
Footage shared on Telegram of people seeking treatment on the beach.
Credit: TelegramFootage on Russian state television showed people running from a beach and some people being carried off on sun loungers.
Russian-installed authorities in Crimea said missile fragments had fallen just after noon near a beach on the north side of the city of Sevastopol where locals were on holiday.

The possible attack by Yemen’s Houthi terrorists near the outer reaches of the Gulf of Aden came as a U.S. aircraft carrier is heading for home.
The attack was just off to the northeast of Yemen’s Socotra Island, also held by allies of the exiled government.
“The master of a merchant vessel reports an explosion in close proximity to the vessel,” the UKMTO said.
In May, a Portuguese-flagged container ship came under attack by a drone in the far reaches of the Arabian Sea in an attack claimed by the Houthis.
The Houthis have maintained that their attacks target ships linked to Israel, the United States or Britain.

The attack was just off to the northeast of Yemen's Socotra Island, also held by allies of the exiled government.
“The master of a merchant vessel reports an explosion in close proximity to the vessel,” the UKMTO said.
“The crew are reported safe and the vessel is proceeding to its next port of call.”It offered no other immediate information about the attack.
Of the more than 60 attacks launched by the Houthis since November that specifically targeted vessels, this would be one of the furthest.
In May, a Portuguese-flagged container ship came under attack by a drone in the far reaches of the Arabian Sea in an attack claimed by the Houthis.

The attack was just off to the northeast of Yemen's Socotra Island, also held by allies of the exiled government.
“The master of a merchant vessel reports an explosion in close proximity to the vessel,” the UKMTO said.
“The crew are reported safe and the vessel is proceeding to its next port of call.”It offered no other immediate information about the attack.
Of the more than 60 attacks launched by the Houthis since November that specifically targeted vessels, this would be one of the furthest.
However, the distance at which it was struck led experts to question whether Iran, the Houthis' main benefactor, could have launched the attack.

Suspected Yemen Houthi attack targets vessel in waters further away than many previous assaultsDUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) — A possible attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels on Monday targeted a ship further away from nearly all of the previous assaults they've launched in the Gulf of Aden, officials said, potentially part of a widening escalation by the group.
The attack was just off to the northeast of Yemen's Socotra Island, also held by allies of the exiled government.
“The master of a merchant vessel reports an explosion in close proximity to the vessel,” the UKMTO said.
“The crew are reported safe and the vessel is proceeding to its next port of call.”It offered no other immediate information about the attack.
Of the more than 60 attacks launched by the Houthis since November that specifically targeted vessels, this would be one of the furthest.

Of the more than 60 attacks launched by the Houthis since November that specifically targeted vessels, this would be one of the furthest.
However, the distance at which it was struck led experts to question whether Iran, the Houthis' main benefactor, could have launched the attack.

A possible attack by Yemen’s Houthi rebels on Monday targeted a ship farther away from nearly all of the previous assaults they’ve launched in the Gulf of Aden, officials said, potentially part of a widening escalation by the group.
The attack was just off to the northeast of Yemen’s Socotra Island, also held by allies of the exiled government.
“The master of a merchant vessel reports an explosion in close proximity to the vessel,” the UKMTO said.
“JMIC assesses that the vessel was likely attacked due to perceived Israeli association.”Another MSC-associated vessel, the MSC Orion, was targeted in May in a deep-sea attack claimed by the Houthis.
Of the more than 60 attacks launched by the Houthis since November that specifically targeted vessels, this would be one of the farthest.

The attack was just off to the northeast of Yemen’s Socotra Island, also held by allies of the exiled government.
“The master of a merchant vessel reports an explosion in close proximity to the vessel,” the UKMTO said.
“JMIC assesses that the vessel was likely attacked due to perceived Israeli association.”Another MSC-associated vessel, the MSC Orion, was targeted in May in a deep-sea attack claimed by the Houthis.
Al-Masirah, a satellite news channel run by the Houthis, highlighted the attack on the MSC Sarah V early Tuesday, without claiming the assault.
Of the more than 60 attacks launched by the Houthis since November that specifically targeted vessels, this would be one of the farthest.

Founded in 1982 during Lebanon’s civil war, Hezbollah’s initial objective was ending Israel’s occupation of southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah and Israel fought a monthlong war that ended in a draw but Israeli bombardment wreaked widespread destruction in southern Lebanon.

BEIRUT — After more than eight months of low-scale conflict, Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah are threatening all-out war.
Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah have recently ratcheted up their threats of an all-out war.
Hezbollah and Israel fought a monthlong war that ended in a draw but Israeli bombardment wreaked widespread destruction in southern Lebanon.
Israel and the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah have recently ratcheted up their threats of an all-out war.
Throughout its latest conflict with Israel, Hezbollah has gradually introduced new weapons to its arsenal, especially after Israel began its ground invasion of the southern city of Rafah in Gaza in early May.

The Russian Foreign Ministry on Monday claimed U.S.-made missiles were used in a deadly weekend attack on Russia-annexed Crimea.
It added U.S.-supplied ATACMS missiles were used in the attack, which reportedly killed four people and injured more than 150 others.
Western-supplied weaponry has been used by Ukrainian forces throughout Kyiv’s war with Russia, which began more than three years ago.
Western allies have previously declared Crimea, which Russia annexed from Ukraine in 2014, is a fair target for Ukraine, the AP noted.
Those killed in Sunday’s attack included two children who were hit by falling debris from Ukrainian missiles shot down near Sevastopol, a port city in Crimea, the AP reported, citing Russian officials.

The Russian Foreign Ministry summoned the American ambassador on Monday to protest what it says was the use of U.S.-made advanced missiles in a Ukrainian attack on Russian-annexed Crimea that reportedly killed four people and wounded more than 150.
The Associated Press could not independently verify Russia's claims about the missiles used.
But as Ukraine has at times struggled to hold the line against Russia’s bigger and better-equipped military, Western leaders have gradually relented and granted more support.
Russian authorities said that the dead in Sunday’s attack included two children who were hit by falling debris from Ukrainian missiles that were shot down over a coastal area in Sevastopol, a port city in Crimea.
Russia said the missiles were U.S.-made ATACMS, a long-range, guided missile.

Russia appears to be placing military facilities near civilian areas in Crimea to deter Ukrainian strikes, experts sayRussia appears to be placing military facilities near civilian areas in Crimea to deter Ukrainian strikes, experts sayRussia accused Ukraine of injuring civilians in an ATACMS attack on Crimea on Sunday.
Russia is likely placing military facilities near civilians to deter Ukrainian strikes, experts say.
Russia is likely placing military facilities near civilian areas in Crimea to try to deter further Ukrainian strikes, military analysts said.
Placing potential military targets near civilian infrastructure is a strategy Russia has leveraged in the past, with the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant and schools in occupied Ukraine used to shield Russian military equipment, the ISW reported.
However, in doing so, Russia is likely breaking its own International Humanitarian Law, which says that military command must refrain from placing military targets close to or in highly populated areas.

Russia appears to be placing military facilities near civilian areas in Crimea to deter Ukrainian strikes, experts sayBusiness Insider via Yahoo ^ | June 24th, 2024 | Thibault SpirletPosted on by MarinerRussia is likely placing military facilities near civilian areas in Crimea to try to deter further Ukrainian strikes, military analysts said.
ISW should be publicly challenged to identify the Russian military infrastructure they charge is embedded on the beach.
To: Mariner“Russia appears to be placing military facilities near civilian areas in Crimea to deter Ukrainian strikes, experts say” Yep, just what we thought.
*I guess they figured that the people there with one and two piece bathing suits were the latest design of Russian military uniforms.
by 20 posted onby ansel12 ((NATO warrior under Reagan, and RA under Nixon, bemoaning the pro-Russians from Vietnam to Ukraine.))

Israeli officials have threatened a military offensive in Lebanon if there is no negotiated end to push Hezbollah away from the border.
U.S. President Joe Biden’s senior adviser, Amos Hochstein, met with officials in Lebanon and Israel last week in an effort to deescalate tensions.
It is harder to fend off the shorter-range rockets that Hezbollah fires routinely across the border into Israel, he said.
The situation escalated this month after an Israeli airstrike killed a senior Hezbollah military commander in southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah retaliated by firing hundreds of rockets and explosive drones into northern Israel and Israel responded with a heavy assault on the militant group.

The United States' top military officer has warned that an Israeli military offensive into Lebanon would risk an Iranian response in defence of the powerful Hezbollah militant group there, triggering a broader war that could put American forces in the region in danger.
READ MORE: Israeli military straps injured Palestinian man to hood of jeepChairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff General CQ Brown has warned an Israeli offensive into Lebanon risks dragging Iran into the Middle East conflict.
(AP Photo/Kevin Wolf) (AP)Israeli officials have threatened a military offensive in Lebanon if there is no negotiated end to push Hezbollah away from the border.
US President Joe Biden's senior adviser, Amos Hochstein, met with officials in Lebanon and Israel last week in an effort to deescalate tensions.
The situation escalated this month after an Israeli airstrike killed a senior Hezbollah military commander in southern Lebanon.

BEIRUT — Thousands of fighters from Iran-backed groups in the Middle East are ready to come to Lebanon to join with the militant group Hezbollah in its battle with Israel if the simmering conflict escalates into a full-blown war, officials with Iran-backed factions and analysts say.
Almost daily exchanges of fire have occurred along Lebanon’s frontier with northern Israel since fighters from the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip staged a bloody assault on southern Israel in early October that set off a war in Gaza.
The situation to the north worsened this month after an Israeli airstrike killed a senior Hezbollah military commander in southern Lebanon.
Hezbollah retaliated by firing hundreds of rockets and explosive drones into northern Israel.
Israeli officials have threatened a military offensive in Lebanon if there is no negotiated deal to push Hezbollah away from the border.

Palestinian inspects the damages at Al-Daraj clinic which was hit in an Israeli strike in Gaza City June 24, 2024.
PHOTO: REUTERSAn Israeli air strike at a medical clinic in Gaza City killed the director of Gaza's Ambulance and Emergency Department, the enclave's health ministry said, while Israel's military said the strike had killed a senior Hamas armed commander.
The health ministry said the killing of Hani al-Jaafarawi brought the number of medical staff killed by Israeli fire since Oct 7 to 500.
Mourners attend the funeral of Palestinian Hani Al-Jaafarwi, the director of ambulance and emergency services at the ministry of health, who was killed in an Israeli strike on Al-Daraj clinic, in Gaza City.
The Israeli offensive in retaliation has killed almost 37,600 people, according to Palestinian health authorities, and has left Gaza in ruins.

One strike at a food distribution centre in Gaza City, near the Shati historic refugee camp, killed three people.
Another, near Bani Suhaila town in the southern Gaza Strip, killed at least eight, including guards who accompany aid trucks, the medics said.
Overnight, an Israeli air strike at a medical clinic in Gaza City killed the director of Gaza's Ambulance and Emergency Department, the enclave's health ministry said.
Hamas says any agreement must end the war, while Israel says it will agree only temporary pauses in fighting until Hamas is eradicated.
The Israeli offensive in retaliation has killed almost 37,600 people, according to Palestinian health authorities, and has left Gaza in ruins.

Israel and Hezbollah each have lessons from their last war, in 2006, a monthlong conflict that ended in a draw.
A United Nations resolution ending the war called for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon and a demilitarized zone on Lebanon’s side of the border.
Iran-backed Hezbollah initially seemed caught off-guard by Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack on Israel, a regional ally, but began firing rockets into northern Israel the following day.
In a war with Hezbollah, there would be no point in additional evacuations since the militia’s rockets and missiles can reach all of Israel.
A full-scale war would likely spread to multiple fronts, escalating the involvement of Iranian proxies in Syria, Iraq and Yemen — and perhaps draw in Iran itself.

Israel and Hezbollah each have lessons from their last war, in 2006, a monthlong conflict that ended in a draw.
The 2006 war, six years after Israeli forces that had occupied southern Lebanon withdrew, erupted after Hezbollah captured two Israeli soldiers and killed several others in a cross-border raid.
A United Nations resolution ending the war called for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon and a demilitarized zone on Lebanon’s side of the border.
Iran-backed Hezbollah initially seemed caught off-guard by Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack on Israel, a regional ally, but began firing rockets into northern Israel the following day.
In a war with Hezbollah, there would be no point in additional evacuations since the militia’s rockets and missiles can reach all of Israel.

Lebanon has no such network, and shelters would be of little use against massive “bunker buster” bombs Israel has dropped in some parts of Gaza.

With another setback for cease-fire talks, worries of full-scale war for Israel and Lebanon escalateBEIRUT (AP) — The prospect of a full-scale war between Israel and Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group terrifies people on both sides of the border, but some see it as an inevitable fallout from Israel’s ongoing war against Hamas in Gaza, particularly as cease-fire negotiations have faltered.
Israel and Hezbollah each have lessons from their last war, in 2006, a monthlong conflict that ended in a draw.
The 2006 war, six years after Israeli forces that had occupied southern Lebanon withdrew, erupted after Hezbollah captured two Israeli soldiers and killed several others in a cross-border raid.
A United Nations resolution ending the war called for withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon and a demilitarized zone on Lebanon’s side of the border.
In a war with Hezbollah, there would be no point in additional evacuations since the militia’s rockets and missiles can reach all of Israel.

messages.message:
In this photo provided by Fighters For A Free North Korea, North Korean defector Park Sang-hak, left, and a member of Fighters For A Free North Korea hold balloons bearing anti-North Korean propaganda leaflets in Paju, near the border with North Korea, South Korea, Thursday, June 20, 2024.
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — North Korea resumed launches of balloons likely carrying trash toward South Korea on Monday night, South Korea’s military said, in the latest round of a Cold War-style campaign on the Korean Peninsula.
The statement asked South Korean citizens not to touch North Korean balloons and report them to military and police authorities.
North Korea has reacted to past South Korean loudspeaker broadcasts and civilian balloon activities by firing rounds across the border, prompting South Korea to return fire, according to South Korea.
The trash also included jeans, a banned item in North Korea; South Korean clothes that were badly damaged, likely by knives or scissors; and other items with imitation Disney characters.

South Korean Joint Chiefs of Staff spokesperson Lee Sung Joon told reporters Monday that the military is closely monitoring North Korean moves because northerly or northwesterly winds, favorable for North Korean balloon launches, were forecast on Monday.
North Korea said its balloon campaign was a tit-for-tat action against South Korean activists who flew political leaflets critical of its leadership across the border.
A balloon believed to have been sent by North Korea, carrying various objects including what appeared to be trash, is pictured in Incheon, South Korea.
The South Korean military didn't say how it would respond if North Korea conducts a new round of balloon launches.
North Korea has reacted to past South Korean loudspeaker broadcasts and civilian balloon activities by firing rounds across the border, prompting South Korea to return fire, according to South Korea.

North Korea has flown balloons carrying trash since late May, with hundreds landing in South Korea.
South Korea deployed military explosives units and chemical and biological warfare teams to inspect the objects.
North Korea, which suffers a chronic food shortage, depended on South Korea for massive shipments of chemical fertiliser until such aid was suspended in 2007 as Pyongyang accelerated weapons development.
Last week, the North warned it would send more balloons carrying trash.
ALSO READ: South Korea to suspend military pact with North over trash balloons

North Korea has flown balloons carrying trash since late May, with hundreds landing in South Korea.
South Korea deployed military explosives units and chemical and biological warfare teams to inspect the objects.
North Korea has said the balloons were retaliation for a propaganda campaign by North Korean defectors and activists in the South who regularly send over balloons carrying food, medicine, money and leaflets criticising the North's leaders.
North Korea, which suffers a chronic food shortage, depended on South Korea for massive shipments of chemical fertilizer until such aid was suspended in 2007 as Pyongyang accelerated weapons development.
Last week, the North warned it would send more balloons carrying trash.

Both sides have prevented the tit-for-tat attacks from escalating into a full-blown war, recognizing the likely catastrophic consequences.
As a scholar of Lebanon and Israel, I have closely followed the domestic dynamics in both countries.
Regional dynamicsHezbollah, a group that is seen as a proxy of Iran but with its own domestic concerns, risks dragging Lebanon into a war unwanted by most Lebanese.
Russia, supported by Iran in its war against Ukraine, is watching too, viewing this conflict as a means to weaken the United States.
Potential for US-Iran conflictA full war between Israel and Hezbollah would likely set the entire region on fire, involving Iran and its proxies.

Both sides have prevented the tit-for-tat attacks from escalating into a full-blown war, recognizing the likely catastrophic consequences.
Iran’s regional rivals, particularly Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states, are closely monitoring how Iran uses the Gaza conflict and growing violence on the Lebanon-Israel border to advance its regional interests.
Russia, supported by Iran in its war against Ukraine, is watching too, viewing this conflict as a means to weaken the United States.
Potential for US-Iran conflictA full war between Israel and Hezbollah would likely set the entire region on fire, involving Iran and its proxies.
In Israel, the pressure from conservative and religious sectors and from residents of the north to go to war with Hezbollah is mounting.

The comments threatened to further heighten the tensions between Israel and Hezbollah at a time when they appear to be moving closer to war.
Netanyahu also signaled that there is no end in sight for the grinding war in Gaza.
The Iranian-backed Hezbollah began striking Israel almost immediately after Hamas’ Oct. 7 cross-border attack that triggered the Gaza war.
In the interview, Netanyahu said that Israel’s offensive in Gaza is winding down.
Netanyahu ruled out one option favored by some of his ultranationalist governing partners — re-settling Israelis in Gaza.

Netanyahu also signaled that there is no end in sight for the grinding war in Gaza.
The Iranian-backed Hezbollah began striking Israel almost immediately after Hamas’ Oct. 7 cross-border attack that triggered the Gaza war.
In the interview, Netanyahu said that Israel’s offensive in Gaza is winding down.
But he said Israel would have to continue “mowing” operations — targeted strikes aimed at preventing Hamas from regrouping.
Netanyahu ruled out one option favored by some of his ultranationalist governing partners — re-settling Israelis in Gaza.

But directly blaming the United States for an attack on Crimea — which Russia unilaterally annexed in 2014 although most of the world considers it part of Ukraine — is a step further.
Russia said the United States had supplied the weapons, while the U.S. military had aimed them and provided data.
Ambassador Lynne Tracy and told her Washington was "waging a hybrid war against Russia and has actually become a party to the conflict."
After the United States allowed Ukraine to direct some U.S. weapons into Russia, the Kremlin sent signals that it viewed this as a serious escalation.
"Of course, the involvement of the United States in the fighting, as a result of which peaceful Russians are dying, cannot but have consequences," Peskov said.

The Kremlin on Monday squarely blamed the United States for an attack on Crimea with US-supplied ATACMS missiles that killed at least four people and injured 151, and Moscow formally warned the US ambassador that retaliation would follow.
But directly blaming the United States for an attack on Crimea - which Russia unilaterally annexed in 2014 although most of the world considers it part of Ukraine - is a step further.
Russia said the United States had supplied the weapons, while the US military had aimed them and provided data.
After the United States allowed Ukraine to direct some US weapons into Russia, the Kremlin sent signals that it viewed this as a serious escalation.
"Of course, the involvement of the United States in the fighting, as a result of which peaceful Russians are dying, cannot but have consequences," Peskov said.

Long, fraught time line of tensions over Iran's nuclear program ahead of its presidential electionFILE - A worker rides a bike in front of the reactor building of the Bushehr nuclear power plant, just outside the southern city of Bushehr, Iran, on Oct. 26, 2010.
Iran’s nuclear program goes fallow under international pressure.
April 2015 — A framework nuclear deal is announced after months of negotiations, outlining long-term restrictions on Iran’s nuclear program and the removal of many international sanctions.
June 20, 2019 — Iran’s Revolutionary Guard shoots down a U.S. spy drone in the Strait of Hormuz with a surface-to-air missile.
June 28, 2022 — Iran and the United States begin a series of indirect talks in Qatar over the nuclear deal.

June 20, 2019 — Iran’s Revolutionary Guard shoots down a U.S. spy drone in the Strait of Hormuz with a surface-to-air missile.
March 13, 2022 — Iran's Revolutionary Guard claims responsibility for a ballistic missile attack that strikes near the U.S. Consulate in northern Iraq.
June 28, 2022 — Iran and the United States begin a series of indirect talks in Qatar over the nuclear deal.

messages.message:
The Kremlin's army is seeking to press its advantages in troop numbers and weaponry before Ukrainian forces are bulked up by promised new Western military aid that is already trickling to the front line, analysts say.
It dashes to positions and without delay fires a Soviet-era Pion self-propelled howitzer at Russian positions before it can be targeted itself.
A six-month delay in U.S. aid threw Ukraine's military onto the defensive.
Meantime, it said, ''Russian forces are attempting to make tactically and operationally significant gains'' before it arrives.
Russia has pounded Kharkiv in recent months, apparently to draw some Ukrainian forces away from the defense of Donetsk while trying to create a buffer zone to prevent cross-border Ukrainian attacks.

Russia keeps up the front-line pressure before Ukraine receives a boost from Western military aidDONETSK REGION, Ukraine (AP) — Relentless Russian attacks on Ukrainian positions defending the strategically important eastern city of Chasiv Yar are disrupting troop rotations and the delivery of some supplies, soldiers in the area say.
A six-month delay in U.S. aid threw Ukraine’s military onto the defensive.
Meantime, it said, “Russian forces are attempting to make tactically and operationally significant gains” before it arrives.
Russia has pounded Kharkiv in recent months, apparently to draw some Ukrainian forces away from the defense of Donetsk while trying to create a buffer zone to prevent cross-border Ukrainian attacks.
___Follow AP’s coverage of the war in Ukraine at https://apnews.com/hub/russia-ukraine© Copyright The Associated Press.

Ukrainian soldiers, of 43rd artillery brigade, fire by 2s7 self-propelled howitzer towards Russian positions at the frontline in Donetsk region, Ukraine, Monday, June 24, 2024.
It dashes to positions and without delay fires a Soviet-era Pion self-propelled howitzer at Russian positions before it can be targeted itself.
A six-month delay in U.S. aid threw Ukraine’s military onto the defensive.
Meantime, it said, “Russian forces are attempting to make tactically and operationally significant gains” before it arrives.
Russia has pounded Kharkiv in recent months, apparently to draw some Ukrainian forces away from the defense of Donetsk while trying to create a buffer zone to prevent cross-border Ukrainian attacks.

The Kremlin’s army is seeking to press its advantages in troop numbers and weaponry before Ukrainian forces are bulked up by promised new Western military aid that is already trickling to the front line, analysts say.
It dashes to positions and without delay fires a Soviet-era Pion self-propelled howitzer at Russian positions before it can be targeted itself.
Meantime, it said, “Russian forces are attempting to make tactically and operationally significant gains” before it arrives.
Russia has pounded Kharkiv in recent months, apparently to draw some Ukrainian forces away from the defense of Donetsk while trying to create a buffer zone to prevent cross-border Ukrainian attacks.
___Follow AP’s coverage of the war in Ukraine at https://apnews.com/hub/russia-ukraine
